word.entryDescription: a harm or an injury
word.entryExample: An engineer inspected the wing – luckily, there was no damage.

word.entryDescription: to break, spoil or injure something
word.entryExample: The vandals broke some windows and damaged some furniture in the café.

word.entryDescription: broken, spoiled or injured
word.entryExample: The photo is a bit damaged.

word.entryDescription: to move your body to music
word.entryExample: We're dancing to the music.

word.entryDescription: somebody who dances
word.entryExample: Alex thinks the dancers are great.

word.entryDescription: the possibility of harm or death
word.entryExample: In the bathroom, there's a danger of slipping over on the floor or in the bath or shower.

word.entryDescription: able to cause harm or death
word.entryExample: Car racing is the most dangerous sport.

word.entryDescription: without light
word.entryExample: The forest was dark and she couldn't see the way.

word.entryDescription: a number given to a particular day or year, for example 25 December 2009
word.entryExample: What date is your birthday?

word.entryDescription: your female child
word.entryExample: My daughter looks like me.

word.entryDescription: a period of 24 hours, particularly one that runs from midnight through to the next midnight
word.entryExample: Cats like to sleep during the day and go out at night.

word.entryDescription: two days after today
word.entryExample: I need the money back the day after tomorrow.

word.entryDescription: to handle
word.entryExample: Kate will have to deal with her jealousy if she wants to be friends with Emma again.

word.entryDescription: loved or much liked (used at the beginning of letters)
word.entryExample: Dear Auntie and Uncle, Thank you so much for my brilliant holiday!

word.entryDescription: the punishment of being killed for committing a very serious crime
word.entryExample: The death penalty is the only effective way of stopping criminals from committing violent crimes.

word.entryDescription: a plastic card that makes it possible to pay for your shopping with the money from your bank account
word.entryExample: I don't have a credit card – I think they're dangerous. I just have a debit card.

word.entryDescription: to make a choice after careful thought
word.entryExample: We decided to leave and go back home.

word.entryDescription: a choice that you make
word.entryExample: The first main decision you've got to make is what type of camera do you want.

word.entryDescription: (of a ship, weapon, nuclear reactor, etc) no longer used and taken to pieces
word.entryExample: The power plant has been decommissioned.

word.entryDescription: to decay
word.entryExample: It takes around two months for an apple core to decompose.

word.entryDescription: to make something more attractive by adding something to it
word.entryExample: Designers use lots of things to decorate clothes.

word.entryDescription: a person who paints and decorates houses for a living
word.entryExample: Is your aunt a decorator?

word.entryDescription: to become less
word.entryExample: Many people manage to decrease their weight for a certain time, but then they start eating too much again.

word.entryDescription: great understanding, skills and information about something
word.entryExample: A baby's brain constantly builds a deep knowledge of facial shapes.

word.entryDescription: a serious problem, worry, difficulty, etc
word.entryExample: Miss Green thinks the hospital is in deep trouble.

word.entryDescription: in games such as football (soccer) or hockey - a player whose job is to stop the other team from scoring
word.entryExample: Defenders try to stop the other team scoring goals.

word.entryDescription: without any doubt, certainly
word.entryExample: That fire was definitely arson.

word.entryDescription: cutting down trees on a large scale
word.entryExample: You can see the effects of deforestation from the air.

word.entryDescription: a qualification gained at college or university, or a course leading to this
word.entryExample: Having a good degree will help her get a job.

word.entryDescription: a state where too much water has been lost from the body, or the process of removing water from a substance/compound
word.entryExample: Alcohol causes dehydration of the body.

word.entryDescription: when you have to wait longer than you expect or is normal
word.entryExample: Excuse me, how long is the delay?

word.entryDescription: to make something late
word.entryExample: The plane had been delayed and was arriving ten minutes late.

word.entryDescription: later than planned
word.entryExample: The bus was delayed by a traffic jam.

word.entryDescription: with intention; on purpose, not by chance or mistake
word.entryExample: Coldplay denied copying his music deliberately.

word.entryDescription: with a very pleasant taste or smell
word.entryExample: This chocolate cake is delicious.

word.entryDescription: to carry letters, parcels, goods, etc to their destination
word.entryExample: Martin's newsagent needs new paper boys and girls to deliver newspapers and magazines to our customers.

word.entryDescription: the act of taking letters, parcels, goods, etc to the people they have been sent to, or the things that are brought
word.entryExample: The delivery from an online shop usually takes two weeks.

word.entryDescription: a system or country in which the people elect officials to represent them in government
word.entryExample: People are still attracted to Athens as the birthplace of democracy.

word.entryDescription: somebody who looks after people's teeth
word.entryExample: Mrs Jones is a dentist. She looks after our teeth.

word.entryDescription: to say that something is not true
word.entryExample: The singer denied using music from another song.

word.entryDescription: to leave a place; to go away from
word.entryExample: They departed for France last Monday.

word.entryDescription: a large shop divided into different sections, each selling different kinds of products
word.entryExample: Big department stores sell everything you might want.

word.entryDescription: the act of leaving somewhere
word.entryExample: You should arrive an hour before departure.

word.entryDescription: to rely on (somebody/something)
word.entryExample: An ecosystem is a group of different species living in the same environment which depend on each other to live.

word.entryDescription: an amount of money that you leave when you rent something, which is given back to you if you return it undamaged
word.entryExample: The deposit was paid by Emma's mum.

word.entryDescription: a large dry area with very few plants
word.entryExample: Snakes can live in the desert.

word.entryDescription: to make a plan of something that will be made for real later
word.entryExample: William doesn't want to help design the invitations.

word.entryDescription: the way something has been made; the arrangement of parts of something
word.entryExample: It has the same design but with new case colours.

word.entryDescription: worth having or doing
word.entryExample: Previous experience in cleaning jobs is desirable, but not essential.

word.entryDescription: a strong feeling of wanting to do something
word.entryExample: Children start to smoke partly because of their desire to experiment.
